Issue.Title: [Feature Request]

Activities.Body:
When I look up "last quarter" here:
https://all.devstats.cncf.io/d/5/companies-table?orgId=1&var-period_name=Last%20quarter&var-metric=contributions

I can't tell if it means the last 90 days starting today, or if it means April 1 - June 30, 2021. Maybe I'm missing something but it seems that the dev stats isn't showing this clarification. Maybe an error?

I hope my question makes sense and thanks in advance for your help.
‚ù§ ü§ó
Hmm, I do have data in that chart... maybe you hit a moment when new affiliations were being imported?

@mewzherder, If I understand correctly, it means the last 90 days starting today.

You can refer to the documentation on [annotations](https://github.com/cncf/devstats/blob/master/docs/annotations.md):

```
       time         |                quick_ranges_data                 | quick_ranges_suffix |  quick_ranges_name  
--------------------+--------------------------------------------------+---------------------+---------------------
2014-01-01 04:00:00 | q;3 months;;                                     | q                   | Last quarter
```
The format of `quick_ranges_data` is `suffix;period;from;to`, `Last quarter` corresponds to period `3 months`, this period value will eventually be passed to the metric SQL statement:

https://github.com/cncf/devstatscode/blob/7db39d84210ea63d01086a8f01724202a7da756d/string.go#L15

Actually, this is "last 90 days" starting when that metric was actually calculated - we pre-compute some data, otherwise, this won't be able to run live. So that data might be "Last 90 days" calculated say 2 days ago.

Activities.Body:
Follow up from #289

**NOTE:** This is it for now, I need to think a bit on some of the other dashboards on how best to represent company involvement.

---

## Problem 3 - Companies cannot reasonably measure their involvement

**Feature Request:** On dashboards where `repo_group` is present, allow further filtering by Company.

As a company trying to gauge our involvement within a particular SIG or subproject, we cannot establish what areas we are contributing to because `repo_group` does not provide enough detail (the previous two requests).

Being able to look at the areas, and check company investment helps highlight areas that need potential headcount, or internal re-alignment to ensure the upstream group/repo/subproject remains healthy.

(No examples, please see above requests examples, but think of company metric)


[kubernetes/kubernetes]: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes
[kubernetes/enhancements]: https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements

---

## Dashboards

- Community Sizing and Health Assessment Dashboards
  - GitHub Stats by Repository
  - GitHub Stats by Repository Groups
On it now.

Not quite sure what changs should be added to those two dashes, see you have [Company activity by repos/repo groups](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/8/company-statistics-by-repository-group?orgId=1), if I add company drop-down there, they wil just become this one.
If you really need this, please specify EXACTLY:
- What drop-downs are needed (repo?, repo group? company? contribution type?)
- Multi-value dropdowns? Single-value?
- What data should be displayed on charts? Single value, Stacked companies data? Stacked repo/repo group data? Something else?

I cannot proceed now, because I think you already have that data.

That was my bad, I did completely miss that chart when reviewing them the other day :(

TL;DR I think we can close this, small rant ahead

It is actually a harder than I first anticipated. Initially when looking at all the dashboards there was a significant amount of boards that would be beneficial for company data, but then REALLY thinking about how to get meaningful or actionable data out of it, it'd be much harder. e.g. trying to determine if a company is falling behind on reviews and looking at total vs open, but thats not a good indicator because of how reviewers are assigned.

The one place where I think we can get meaningful data out of it is the contributions chart, and adding filter for `sig/*` and `wg/*` labels.

As a company I can then easily our involvement in each sig/wg for enhancements, k/k etc. This is the same for SIG leads and would solve the issue for [sig-security](https://github.com/cncf/devstats/issues/293) since they're largely jut issue based and working out of k/community and would help a few other areas alluded to in my last comment here: https://github.com/cncf/devstats/issues/289#issuecomment-846631395
closing in favor of #299

Activities.Body:
The [PR Reviews by Contributor Dashboard](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/46/pr-reviews-by-contributor?orgId=1) is missing data from pre-2021 for quite a few contributors.

Example query:
https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/46/pr-reviews-by-contributor?orgId=1&from=1569913200000&to=1601535599000&var-period=d&var-repo_name=All&var-reviewers=All

If you scroll down in the list on the right, there will be a bunch of folk with 0's across each column. A few specific contributors that definitely should have entries there:
- johnbelamaric
- xmudrii
- divya-mohan0209
I can take a look at this next week, this week I have a vacation.
I hope, I'll be able to check this tomorrow.
Finally on it.

I can see data for `johnbelamaric` and `divya-mohan0209`, see [this](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/46/pr-reviews-by-contributor?orgId=1&var-period=d7&var-repo_name=All&var-reviewers=%22johnbelamaric%22&var-reviewers=%22divya-mohan0209%22&from=now-90d&to=now).
I'll check `xmudrii` and also those 2 to be sure that the data is OK.
Note that (dashboard documentation):
```
- This dashboard shows number of reviews and lgtms for most active reviewers.
- LGTM means user added /lgtm comment or lgtm label.
- Review means user added PR review comment.
- You can select reviewer from the reviewers drop-down, it shows top active reviewers from last 3 months.
- To find top active reviewers we sum number of reviews and lgtms per user.
```

So to [calculate](https://github.com/cncf/devstats/blob/master/metrics/kubernetes/reviews_per_user.sql) something as a review it must be a comment (not necesarily a review comment) with `/lgtm` somewhere in its body, or adding `lgtm` label or adding a PR review comment (commend body doesn't matter in this case).
Drop down show [top active reviewers](https://github.com/cncf/devstats/blob/master/metrics/shared/reviewers_tags.sql) from the last quarter, so there can be reviewers that were active before tlast quarter or just landed out of top ones - they won't show in the drop-down.

So `johnbelamaric` had 194 reviews in the last quarter, `divya-mohan0209` had 54, `xmudrii ` had 21.
This makes `xmudrii` about 330th reviewer - we're only [showing](https://github.com/cncf/devstatscode/blob/master/tags.go#L61-L65) top 255 reviewers from the last quarter, so thaty user is not listed. The first and the second rank is < 255th so they show up and you can see their reviews [here](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/46/pr-reviews-by-contributor?orgId=1&var-period=d7&var-repo_name=All&var-reviewers=%22johnbelamaric%22&var-reviewers=%22divya-mohan0209%22&from=now-90d&to=now)
I think the data is OK, can we close this @mrbobbytables ?

Ahhh, I did not realize that it was only the top 255.

Yup, should be good to close.

It is possible to have different repo groups on the same repository (the granularity level is a file path within the repo then, but this can also distinguish contributions that actually touch files somehow - most probably commits, etc.), this is used only in kubernetes, for example [here](https://github.com/cncf/devstats/blob/master/util_sql/postprocess_repo_groups.sql).

Activities.Body:
Could you create an API call where we can get the metrics used at the top of [cncf.io](https://www.cncf.io/):
- Number of contributors across all CNCF projects
- Number of contributions across all CNCF projects
- Number of lines of code in all CNCF projects

API implemented, you can call it like this:
`curl -s -H 'Content-Type: application/json' https://devstats.cncf.io/api/v1 -d'{"api":"SiteStats","payload":{"project":"all"}}'`
Response:
```
{"project":"all","db_name":"allprj","contributors":121239,"contributions":5833526,"boc":2022088602}
```

One note: I don't have LOC (lines of code) info, GitHub only gives BOC (bytes of code), so API is returning BOC instead of LOC.

As you can see there is a `project` parameter - when you specify `all` you will get stats for all CNCF projects combined (as requested), but you can also get stats for a particular project, just specify project=kubernetes or grpc or any other CNCF project.
Let me know if you need any other stats, everything that is present in DevStats can also be returned from an API call.
Any idea where LOC is pulled from?  Where did 261M come from?
No, I don't know where it comes from, you can do some tricky assumption that a line of code usually has say 60 bytes or whatever, but in this case, I don't think it comes from DevStats.

See [here](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/repos#list-languages):
```
Lists languages for the specified repository. The value shown for each language is the number of bytes of code written in that language.
```
`bytes of code` - I don't have anything else.
Closing this now, please reopen if you want some more metrics or if there is any other problem with this.

Please add `[bug]` to the issue title when reporting a bug.

https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/9/companies-table

I am checking this table and I would like to know the top x contributors of my current company. Is there's a page I can find the information?

The closest thing would be [click - example for IBM](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/66/developer-activity-counts-by-companies?orgId=1&var-period_name=Last%20decade&var-metric=contributions&var-repogroup_name=All&var-repo_name=kubernetes%2Fkubernetes&var-country_name=All&var-companies=IBM).

You can select a company there, then keep "repository group = all" (so it will count all kubernetes repos across all orgs), then you can choose "metric = contributions". Look at the first table (it's for repository groups, the 2nd one is for specific repo chosen from the "repository" drop down). In my example, it displays stats for IBM.

If you need anything else - you can browse all companies related dashboards by clicking `Developer Activity Counts by Companies` (dashboard name at the top) and then click "Filter by tag" -> companies.

If you still cannot find the correct data you can create a feature request for a new dashboard or ask me to generate some specific data for you (I can create custom reports of whatever data you may need).

@lukaszgryglicki Thanks for your quick response. I just check the example you gave to me and it works fine. Seems there're only "kubernetes" and probably sig repos. checkbox doesn't show other CNCF projects. I am not sure if that's expected? Does CNCF have another global dashboard?

You are on the `Kubernetes` DevStats instance (see URL, it starts k8s.devstats). Each CNCF project has its own instance, for example [gRPC](https://grpc.devstats.cncf.io).

There is also a "summary" instance for [All CNCF](https://all.devstats.cncf.io) projects combined - in this instance, each CNCF project is defined as a separate repository group, so you can use [this](https://all.devstats.cncf.io/d/66/developer-activity-counts-by-companies?orgId=1&var-period_name=Last%20decade&var-metric=contributions&var-repogroup_name=All&var-country_name=All&var-companies=Red%20Hat) (this is a per company contributors statistics for all CNCF projects combined) - there you can play with different companies, different projects (select anything other than "All" from repo group drop-down) and with different metrics (contributions, commits, PRs, etc.)
Thanks @lukaszgryglicki a lot for you guidance!

Issue.Title: 503 Service Temporarily Unavailable

Activities.Body:
This is a follow up from #289, #293, and #295 

Adding a filter for sig/wg labels to the [Contributions chart](https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/74/contributions-chart?orgId=1) will allow SIGS and WGs that work out of shared repos to look at their metrics. With that change it should resolve all our current asks and give sig leads, subproject owners and companies the info they need üëç
Will evaluate as soon as I can, currently a bit busy.
So the first problem is that `filter for sig/wg labels` - this means it can only be applied to issues/PR, not for everything - only issue/PR objects have label(s).

Is this OK for you?
This will find a SIG for the following types of metrics:
- Approves
- Reviews
- Comments
- Issue comments
- Issues
- PRs
- Merged PRs
- Review comments


This will not find SIG for:

- Commit comments
- Commits
- GitHub events (partially, this will count issues PRs, issues/PRs comments, not commits)
- GitHub pushes
- Contributions (partially, it will count issues, PRs, reviews, issue/PR comments, will not count commits).
@mrbobbytables?

I can have one more option - trying to connect commit event (which has commit SHA) with a PR (by using either PR head SHA or PR merge commit SHA), that way I can *try* to correlate PR with commit... but there is no other dashboard doing so, and, actually, I'm not 100% sure if that kind of connection is correct?

That would mean that a commit belongs to a particular SIG when:
- There is a PR that is based on that commit (created from that commit or merged by that commit)
- That PR's issue (in GitHub PR is also an issue, part of its data is stored on the issue object )has a corresponding SIG's `sig/xyz` label.
Makes sense?

let me know if I should continue with that approach, which means
- Issue belongs to SIG if it has a `SIG/xyz` label.
- PR belongs to SIG if its issue has `SIG/xyz` label.
- Approval belongs to SIG if it's an approval of PR described above.
- Review belongs to SIG if it's an approve of PR described above.
- Comment belongs to a SIG if it's a comment on the issue/PR described above.
- Commit belongs to a SIG when it's a commit related to PR described above (merge commit or PR's head commit).

Marking as blocked until this is confirmed.

On the commits/commit comments, do you currently do that by file path? and the internal devstats mapping of which file paths belong to which sig? I was trying to find where that list is in the devstats repo but couldn't find it. >_<

Our OWNERS files tell which sig labels should be applied to PRs that touch files within those directories. e.g.
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/cluster/addons/OWNERS
would apply the labels:
- `sig/cloud-provider`
- `area/provider/gcp`

We have per-file repo groups for [kubernetes](https://github.com/cncf/devstats/blob/master/util_sql/postprocess_repo_groups.sql) - it means that repo group can be different depending on file paths within a single repository (this is for commits, obviously).

But we don't read OWNERS - I cannot do that from SQL level, I only have file path, not its contents there, also those metrics are already quite complex, imagine joining with tables/functions that parse file contents. It would rather need to add additional functionality to parsing (git) comments, when the file name is OWNERS it should parse it and put its contents in files.

And, again, is my idea of connecting commits with PRs correct or not? Because commit and PR are separate GitHub archive events, and all I have to correlate them is SHA on the commits side and PR's head, base and merge commit (for merged PRs) SHAs on the PR side.

Thanks for the path to the repo_groups file, I wasn't sure if that was it or not when I stumbled across it, it only has a couple SIG Cluster Lifecycle stuff in there. >_<  I wasn't trying to push the parsing of owners files on you, I can take a follow up to update that with paths for other SIGs. I was more so just curious about how its currently done. My apologies, that wasn't clear :(

I do like your idea üëç
OK so do the updates - ideally to file paths in that file, so we could avoid parsing `OWNERS`, please also note that I'm on PTO (the only longer PTO this year) since the weekend (two weeks).
No worries, hope you have a good vacation!
Thanks, maybe weren't clear enough - since the next weekend, so if we have file-level changes specified by then, I may at least start working on this.

Issue.Title: [feature request][kubernetes] Add wg/sig label filter to Contributions chart

Activities.Body:
## Problem

DevStats currently does not provide enough granular signal on many of the dashboards to make meaningful inferences from the data. This is largely because `repo_group` is not a good mapping to a particular SIG, and does not provide insight into the subprojects that are repo specific or reflect the work that occurs in shared repos such as [kubernetes/kubernetes], or [kubernetes/enhancements].

This issue outlines 3 problems/requests that could help resolve those problems and make the boards much more useful. It largely boils down to: where `repo_group` is present, add filters for repo, sig/wg label, and Company.

 
---

## Problem 1 - lack of per repo visibility

**Feature Request:** On dashboards where `repo_group` is present, allow further filtering by individual repo.

SIGs have many repos and the work is delegated to subproject owners that own those repos. The current dashboards using `repo_group` do not offer a per-repo breakdown and cannot be used to evaluate the health of a partcular subproject.

**Examples:**
- [Developer Activity Counts by Repository Group] - Without the possibility of a per-repo breakdown, it's difficult to see which repos activity may have dropped.
- [Inactive Issues by SIG] - - While this gives a holestic view of the SIG, without further breakdown by repo it's not possible to see where the problem might actually exist.
- [Awaiting PRs by SIG] - Same as the above Inactive Issue board.



[Developer Activity Counts by Repository Group]: https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/13/developer-activity-counts-by-repository-group?orgId=1
[Inactive Issues by SIG]: https://k8s.devstats.cncf.io/d/73/inactive-issues-by-sig?orgId=1

## Problem 2 - lack of per SIG/WG break down in shared repos

**Feature Request:** on dashboards where `repo_group` is present, allow further filtering by SIG label.

Some SIGs/WGs work almost exclusively out of shared repos such as [kubernetes/kubernetes] or [kubernetes/enhancement]; repo_group does not capture their work.

**Examples:**
- [SIG Scalability Repository Groups] - SIG Scalability is near 100% out of [kubernetes/kubernetes].
- [SIG Auth Repository Groups] - The majority of SIG Auth's work occurs in [kubernetes/kubernetes] with the repos listed here being subprojects or initatives under a working group.

## Problem 3 - Companies cannot reasonably measure their involvement

**Feature Request:** On dashboards where `repo_group` is present, allow further filtering by Company.

As a company trying to gauge our involvement within a particular SIG or subproject, we cannot establish what areas we are contributing to because `repo_group` does not provide enough detail (the previous two requests).

Being able to look at the areas, and check company investment helps highlight areas that need potential headcount, or internal re-alignment to ensure the upstream group/repo/subproject remains healthy.

(No examples, please see above requests examples, but think of company metric)
